items: Signs and symptoms of endocarditis infection involving either native or prosthetic valve.
Positive blood or valve cultures for Candida sp.
Valve replacement strongly recommended whenever possible, particularly in those with prosthetic valve endocarditis.

regimenData.notes: in stable patients with negative blood cultures and fluconazole susceptible organism

items: One of the above primary or alternative regimens followed by Fluconazole 400-800 mg/day for 6 months.
Treat for at least 6 weeks after valve replacement, longer in those with complications (e.g., perivalvular or myocardial abscess, extensive disease, delayed resolution of candidemia).
Long-term, possibly life-long, suppression with Fluconazole 400-800 mg/day for prosthetic valve endocarditis if no valve replacement (Medicine 90:237, 2011).

Fluconazole monotherapy not recommended as primary treatment due to high failure rate; but may be used as a single agent following primary therapy for long-term suppression (Medicine 90:237, 2011). One observational study of prosthetic valve IE due to candida suggested that lipid-based Amphotericin B may be more effective than echinocandin therapy (Clin Infect Dis 66:825, 2018). However, mortality rate was high and surgery did not seem to be helpful.
References: IDSA treatment guidelines: Clin Infect Dis 62:409, 2016 and Curr Opin Infect Dis 26:501, 2013.
